metadata.name: I'm in the world, but I'm not of it #157
metadata.description:
This piece resembles an abstract physical painting, but does not hide the hard edges and polygons that show its digital origins.

The title of this piece comes from "I'm in the world" by Moondog.

Libraries: p5.js

issuer.name: I'm in the world, but I'm not of it

metadata.name: "Attack on Titan" #17
metadata.description:
You have probably seen the Attack on Titan anime or at least heard of it!
A world where humans try to destroy titans.
The movements of humans to destroy them are fast, but the movement of titans is slow and they cannot react.
In this work, an attempt has been made to revive this world to some extent.
As you can see, none of the elements overlap completely, and by using the algorithm, they can overlap with the head of the titan only sometimes (the way to kill the titans) and the movements of humans and titans are simulated.

metadata.name: Tesseract #55
metadata.description:
'Tesseract' is a generative collection drawing on the concept of the cube from oneirology, the interpretation of dreams. In many mythologies and fields of study, the square is considered a 'perfect shape', thus with its abstraction into three isometric dimensions, the cube is seen by some as a representation of the various aspects of the human condition.

In 'Tesseract', the ribbons flowing between the cubes represent the shared experiences that connect us all. No matter how different our lives might be, we all go through the same joys, sorrows, trials, tribulations and experience attachments of varying degrees. 

It is these experiences that bind us together and make us who we are. With these concepts in mind, viewers are invited to interpret each composition as it relates to them and their unique story, from the perspective of that which has been and that which is yet to be experienced.

Press 'S' to save a high resolution PNG at 2400 x 3396 px.

metadata.name: Richter #495
metadata.description:
Richter is the second collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog, following their first project called Gerhard. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time.
 
Richter works with data from 4 of 24 highres images, 30mb in total. This is the maximum size fxhash allows for a project and three times more than Gerhard. Richard Nadler created stunning new textures, enabling more variation in composition and detail to emerge at much higher resolution. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Richter elevates the approach from Gerhard with new methods for the realtime rendering process and new features like offline-first caching. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels as data.
 
Richter is featured in the exhibition "Generative Abstraction" at Expanded.art in Berlin.
 
- Click to start a new layer of motion and color.
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen.
- Press “s” to save the canvas.
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

leanderherzog.ch/2023/richter/
leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/
fxhash.xyz/generative/17030/

metadata.name: Gerhard #438
metadata.description:
Gerhard is a collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog on fxhash. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time. 
Richard Nadler created the textures to control composition and color. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels. This collaboration is enabled by twitter and fxhash, as the generative art community continues to explore abstraction in summer 2022 – while extreme temperatures, wildfires, ongoing conflicts and volatile markets continue to escalate. 

- Click to start a new layer of motion and color. 
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen mode. 
- Press “s” to save the current canvas. 
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

https://leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/

metadata.name: Cheap Petri Dish #61
metadata.description:
Emulating a petridish using Reaction Diffusion Algorithm. 
5 Diffusion Styles + 1800 Color Styles + Eraser to interact with the petridish.
Press 'o' for skeleton & 'p' for performance
Scales with resolution

metadata.name: Obscure Archive #75
metadata.description:
Tabula rasa - we are all born without mental condition built-in, therefore knowledge and emotions come from experience.

As we grow up, emotions and feelings come to us naturally. Joy, sadness, anger, tranquility, confusion - to name a few, all these emotions makes us who we are today consciously or subconsciously. Yet, negative emotions are easier to remember and sticks longer compared to the positive ones.

Though, some people are lucky enough to be able to express their emotions freely to their surrounding, letting others know what they're feeling & what they've been through. While some other finds it harder to let go of those negative emotions. Wanting them to be gone but, alas, they can't find the right conditions to do so. Or even worse, these emotions get mixed up and tangled with their thoughts and memories making it harder to read or express.

__________

Obscure Archive is trying to capture what I (or maybe, you too) have been feeling constantly. These negative emotions is expressed and written as the text within the artwork, with the supergraphic representing thoughts & memories that we have. Some of the artwork has no overlay, just like those who can express their emotions freely. While some other have a completely different overlay, with messy text and supergraphic representing the concealment & entangled thoughts that make the emotions harder to read.

__________

made with ❤️ and p5js

metadata.name: Orbital Plowing v1.1 #17
metadata.description:
This is a special edition of Orbital Plowing v1.0 which is free for first minting. I'm putting it out as a limited release with some organization imposed on the placement of the beads. Hopefully someone will find a rare one with 8 spheres!

Royalties will be shared with THREE.js and Girls Who Code as I have chosen to support both causes in all of my work starting with Orbital Plowing v1.0.

Continuing my experiment to create very realistic glass spheres that can be manipulated and moved within the THREE.js environment. The glass spheres move in unusual orbital paths plowing through a field of hundreds of plastic beads of various sizes.

Extremely rare to get 8 glass spheres... By the randomness imposed, 30% will have one sphere, 30% two, 20% three, 10% four, 5% five, 3.5% six, 1% seven and 0.5% eight. Happy hunting!

Interactive with several user controls:

With the mouse:

Left click and drag to change the viewing angle
Right click and drag to change the view center
Mouse wheel to change the distance to the view center

With the keyboard:

Keys "," and "." (i.e. "<" and ">") change the rotation speed left or right. You can stop it entirely, or speed it up to what I consider a reasonable maximum, rotating to the left or to the right. Each time you press, it adjusts the rotation speed.

Press "a" to change the lighting angle.
